note.p: “Of various trees a vista green” (MS VIII; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—In MS VIII, the twenty-six lines beginning with this line appear on 64r-v, divided by a horizontal line from the preceding titled draft of the poem, "Lago di Como", and by a line space from the following untited poem, "It was an eve of summer, mild" ["Lago Maggiore"]. On 79r, the line “Of various trees a vista green” recurs, along with the two following lines from 64r, as lines 19-21 (numbered by Ruskin 1395-97) of the titled draft of the poem, "Genoa". There, the lines 19 and 21 are followed by "&c" and "&", respectively, apparently indicating that the full twenty-six lines on 64r-v are to be inserted at that designated point of the draft of "Genoa". The intention of these "etcetera" symbols is supported by the correspondingly metadiscursive symbol of four asterisks, which follow the final, twenty-sixth line of the earlier poem on 64r-v. Yet, despite these asterisks, no evidence definitively establishes that Ruskin initially composed the twenty-six lines of “Of various trees a vista green” as a fragment destined specifically for "Genoa", or that he composed these lines out of sequence and at a different time from the verse surrounding them. While the metadiscursive marks make Ruskin's intentions clear enough for inserting the lines in the draft fifteen pages later, the twenty-six lines of “Of various trees a vista green” assert a measure of ontological status as a poetic utterance. In Poems (1891), W. G. Collingwood inserted the lines into "Genoa" without comment, and the editors of the Library Edition followed suit, without remarking the separation of the lines in the manuscript as a unit apart from the longer poem.

Respecting the sequence of composition at this stage in MS VIII, one can broadly claim that, following draft of a cluster of poems concerning crossing the Alps (see “Passing the Alps” and glosses), Ruskin reverted to drafting prose for the earlier Belgian segment of the journey, presumably in order to keep pace with his simultaneous fair-copying and illustration of that portion of the "Account" in MS IX. Interspersed with these essays, he introduced verse about northern Italy, his invention logically adverting first to the Italian lakes, as the geographical introduction to Italy following an Alpine crossing from the north. He composed a poem about Chiavenna, “Oh softly blew the morning breeze”, and “Lago di Como”, and then this poem about the journey south to Genoa. He skipped writing here about Milan, presumably because he had already composed “Milan Cathedral” in MS IA, g.2. Thus, the vista of a “rich and mighty plain” that opens at the start of this poem refers to the country south of Milan, and the poem surveys a wide panoramic arc from north to south.

“Thither and thither” (MS VIII; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Collingwood altered this phrase to "Hither and thither", and the Library Edition silently accepted the emendation (Poems [4o, 1891], and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:154; Ruskin, Works, 2:378). Ruskin's additional modifier "fast" suggests, however, that he did intend that the "sportive light ran / Thither and thither fast", receding rapidly away from the spectator "through / That natural arched avenue", and not that the light ran randomly "hither and thither" on the surface of the water.

“Pale gleams of icy sun came forth” (MS VIII; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Collingwood read a smeared word in the manuscript as "sun", and the Library Edition silently accepted this reading, though the intended word may be "snow" (Poems [4o, 1891], and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:154; Ruskin, Works, 2:379). A definitive reading may not be possible, but the following adjectival phrases, "Wnite as the wreathed salt sea spray / With the the snow wreaths that ever press", read less redundantly if modifying the whiteness of sunlight rather than snow.
